org.semanticweb.rulewerk.core.reasoner

Interface Reasoner

  • All Superinterfaces:
    AutoCloseable, KnowledgeBaseListener
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    VLogReasoner

    public interface Reasoner
extends AutoCloseable, KnowledgeBaseListener
    Interface that exposes the (existential) rule reasoning capabilities of a Reasoner.
    The knowledge base of the reasoner can be loaded with explicit facts and existential rules that would infer implicit facts trough reasoning.
    Facts can be added to the knowledge base:
    • as in-memory Java objects (Fact)
    • from a persistent data source (DataSourceDeclaration)

    Rules added to the knowledge base can be re-written internally by VLog, using the corresponding set RuleRewriteStrategy.

    The loaded reasoner can perform atomic queries on explicit and implicit facts after calling reason(). Queries can provide an iterator for the results (answerQuery(PositiveLiteral, boolean), or the results can be exported to a file (exportQueryAnswersToCsv(PositiveLiteral, String, boolean)).

    Reasoning with various Algorithms is supported, that can lead to different sets of inferred facts and different termination behavior. In some cases, reasoning with rules with existentially quantified variables (ExistentialVariable) may not terminate. We recommend reasoning with algorithm Algorithm.RESTRICTED_CHASE, as it leads to termination in more cases. To avoid non-termination, a reasoning timeout can be set (setReasoningTimeout(Integer)).
    Author:
    Irina Dragoste

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static interface  Reasoner.InferenceAction
      Interface for actions to perform on inferences.

      • setAlgorithm

        void setAlgorithm(Algorithm algorithm)
        Sets the algorithm that will be used for reasoning over the knowledge base. If no algorithm is set, the default algorithm is Algorithm.RESTRICTED_CHASE will be used.
        Parameters:
        algorithm - the algorithm to be used for reasoning.

      • getAlgorithm

        Algorithm getAlgorithm()
        Getter for the algorithm that will be used for reasoning over the knowledge base. The default value is Algorithm.RESTRICTED_CHASE.
        Returns:
        the reasoning algorithm.

      • setReasoningTimeout

        void setReasoningTimeout(Integer seconds)
        In some cases, reasoning with rules with existentially quantified variables (ExistentialVariable) may not terminate. We recommend reasoning with algorithm Algorithm.RESTRICTED_CHASE, as it leads to termination in more cases.
        This method sets a timeout (in seconds) after which reasoning can be artificially interrupted if it has not reached completion.
        Parameters:
        seconds - interval after which reasoning will be interrupted, in seconds. If null, reasoning will not be interrupted and will return only after (if) it has reached completion.

      • getReasoningTimeout

        Integer getReasoningTimeout()
        This method returns the reasoning timeout, representing the interval (in seconds) after which reasoning will be interrupted if it has not reached completion. The default value is null, in which case reasoning terminates only after (if) it reaches completion.
        Returns:
        if not null, number of seconds after which the reasoning will be interrupted, if it has not reached completion.

      • setRuleRewriteStrategy

        void setRuleRewriteStrategy(RuleRewriteStrategy ruleRewritingStrategy)
        Loaded Rules can be re-written internally to an equivalent set of rules, according to given ruleRewritingStrategy. If no strategy is set, the default value is RuleRewriteStrategy.NONE, meaning that the rules will not be re-written.
        Parameters:
        ruleRewritingStrategy - strategy according to which the rules will be rewritten before reasoning.

      • getRuleRewriteStrategy

        RuleRewriteStrategy getRuleRewriteStrategy()
        Getter for the strategy according to which rules will be rewritten before reasoning. The default value is RuleRewriteStrategy.NONE, meaning that the rules will not be re-written.
        Returns:
        the current rule re-writing strategy

        Parameters:

      • getLogLevel

        LogLevel getLogLevel()
        Returns the logging level of the internal VLog C++ resource. If no value has been set, the default is LogLevel.WARNING.
        Returns:
        the logging level of the VLog C++ resource.

      • setLogFile

        void setLogFile(String filePath)
        Redirects the logs of the internal VLog C++ resource to given file. If no log file is set or the given filePath is not a valid file path, VLog will log to the default system output.
        Parameters:
        filePath - the file for the internal VLog C++ resource to log to. If null or an invalid file path, the reasoner will log to the default system output.

      • checkForCycles

        CyclicityResult checkForCycles()
        Checks whether the loaded rules and loaded fact EDB predicates are Acyclic, Cyclic, or cyclicity cannot be determined.
        Returns:
        the appropriate CyclicityResult.

      • isJA

        boolean isJA()
        Check the Joint Acyclicity (JA) property of loaded rules and EDB predicates of loaded facts. If a set of rules and EDB predicates is JA, then, for the given set of rules and any facts over the given EDB predicates, reasoning by Skolem chase (and, implicitly, the Restricted chase) will always terminate.
        Returns:
        true, if the loaded set of rules is Joint Acyclic with respect to the EDB predicates of loaded facts.
        false, otherwise

      • isRJA

        boolean isRJA()
        Check the Restricted Joint Acyclicity (RJA) property of loaded rules and EDB predicates of loaded facts. If a set of rules and EDB predicates is RJA, then, for the given set of rules and any facts over the given EDB predicates, reasoning by Restricted chase will always terminate
        Returns:
        true, if the loaded set of rules is Restricted Joint Acyclic with respect to the EDB predicates of loaded facts.
        false, otherwise

      • isMFA

        boolean isMFA()
        Check the Model-Faithful Acyclicity (MFA) property of loaded rules and EDB predicates of loaded facts. If a set of rules and EDB predicates is MFA, then, for the given set of rules and any facts over the given EDB predicates, reasoning by Skolem chase (and, implicitly, the Restricted chase) will always terminate
        Returns:
        true, if the loaded set of rules is Model-Faithful Acyclic with respect to the EDB predicates of loaded facts.
        false, otherwise

      • isRMFA

        boolean isRMFA()
        Check the Restricted Model-Faithful Acyclicity (RMFA) property of loaded rules and EDB predicates of loaded facts. If a set of rules and EDB predicates is RMFA, then, for the given set of rules and any facts over the given EDB predicates, reasoning by Restricted chase will always terminate. If a set of rules and EDB predicates is MFA, then it is also JA.
        Returns:
        true, if the loaded set of rules is Restricted Model-Faithful Acyclic with respect to the EDB predicates of loaded facts.
        false, otherwise

      • isMFC

        boolean isMFC()
        Check the Model-Faithful Cyclicity (MFC) property of loaded rules and EDB predicates of loaded facts. If a set of rules and EDB predicates is MFC, then there exists a set of facts over the given EDB predicates for which reasoning by Skolem chase algorithm is guaranteed not to terminate for the loaded rules. If a set of rules and EDB predicates is RMFA, then it is also RJA. Therefore, if a set or rules and EDB predicates is MFC, it is not MFA, nor JA.
        Returns:
        true, if the loaded set of rules is Model-Faithful Cyclic with respect to the EDB predicates of loaded facts.
        false, otherwise

      • reason

        boolean reason()
        throws IOException
        Performs materialisation on the reasoner KnowledgeBase, depending on the set Algorithm. Materialisation implies extending the set of explicit facts in the knowledge base with implicit facts inferred by knowledge base rules.

        In some cases, reasoning with rules with existentially quantified variables ExistentialVariable may not terminate. We recommend reasoning with algorithm Algorithm.RESTRICTED_CHASE, as it leads to termination in more cases.
        To avoid non-termination, a reasoning timeout can be set (setReasoningTimeout(Integer)).
        Returns:
        • true, if materialisation reached completion.
        • false, if materialisation has been interrupted before completion.
        Throws:
        IOException - if I/O exceptions occur during reasoning.

      • answerQuery

        QueryResultIterator answerQuery(PositiveLiteral query,
                                boolean includeNulls)
        Evaluates an atomic query (query) on the implicit facts loaded into the reasoner and the explicit facts materialised by the reasoner.
        An answer to the query is the terms a fact that matches the query: the fact predicate is the same as the query predicate, the Constant terms of the query appear in the answer fact at the same term position, and the Variable terms of the query are matched by terms in the fact, either named (Constant) or anonymous (NamedNull). The same variable name identifies the same term in the answer fact.
        A query answer is represented by a QueryResult. A query can have multiple, distinct query answers. This method returns an Iterator over these answers.
        Depending on the state of the reasoning (materialisation) and its KnowledgeBase, the answers can have a different Correctness (QueryResultIterator.getCorrectness()):
        • If Correctness.SOUND_AND_COMPLETE, materialisation over current knowledge base has completed, and the query answers are guaranteed to be correct.
        • If Correctness.SOUND_BUT_INCOMPLETE, the results are guaranteed to be sound, but may be incomplete. This can happen
          • when materialisation has not completed (reason() returns false),
          • or when the knowledge base was modified after reasoning, and the materialisation does not reflect the current knowledge base. Re-materialisation (reason()) is required in order to obtain complete query answers with respect to the current knowledge base.
        • If Correctness.INCORRECT, the results may be incomplete, and some results may be unsound. This can happen when the knowledge base was modified and the reasoner materialisation is no longer consistent with the current knowledge base. Re-materialisation (reason()) is required, in order to obtain correct query answers.
        Parameters:
        query - a PositiveLiteral representing the query to be answered.
        includeNulls - if true, QueryResults containing terms of type NamedNull (representing anonymous individuals introduced to satisfy rule existentially quantified variables) will be included. Otherwise, the answers will only contain the QueryResults with terms of type Constant (representing named individuals).
        Returns:
        QueryResultIterator that iterates over distinct answers to the query. It also contains the Correctness of the query answers.

      • countQueryAnswers

        default QueryAnswerCount countQueryAnswers(PositiveLiteral query)
        * Evaluates an atomic (query), and counts the number of query answer implicit facts loaded into the reasoner and the number of query answer explicit facts materialised by the reasoner.
        Parameters:
        query - a PositiveLiteral representing the query to be answered.
        Returns:
        a QueryAnswerCount object that contains the query answers Correctness and the number of query answers (i.e. the number of facts in the extension of the query), including answers with NamedNull terms that have been introduced during reasoning. See also countQueryAnswers(PositiveLiteral, boolean).

      • countQueryAnswers

        QueryAnswerCount countQueryAnswers(PositiveLiteral query,
                                   boolean includeNulls)
        Evaluates an atomic (query), and counts the number of query answer implicit facts loaded into the reasoner and the number of query answer explicit facts materialised by the reasoner.
        An answer to the query is the term set of a fact that matches the query: the fact predicate is the same as the query predicate, the TermType.ABSTRACT_CONSTANT, TermType.DATATYPE_CONSTANT and TermType.LANGSTRING_CONSTANT terms of the query appear in the answer fact at the same term position, and the TermType.UNIVERSAL_VARIABLE terms of the query are matched by terms in the fact, either named (any of the three constant types) or anonymous (TermType.NAMED_NULL). The same variable name identifies the same term in the answer fact.
        Depending on the state of the reasoning (materialisation) and its KnowledgeBase, the answers can have a different Correctness (QueryResultIterator.getCorrectness()):
        • If Correctness.SOUND_AND_COMPLETE, materialisation over current knowledge base has completed, and the query answers are guaranteed to be correct.
        • If Correctness.SOUND_BUT_INCOMPLETE, the results are guaranteed to be sound, but may be incomplete. This can happen
          • when materialisation has not completed (reason() returns false),
          • or when the knowledge base was modified after reasoning, and the materialisation does not reflect the current knowledge base. Re-materialisation (reason()) is required in order to obtain complete query answers with respect to the current knowledge base.
        • If Correctness.INCORRECT, the results may be incomplete, and some results may be unsound. This can happen when the knowledge base was modified and the reasoner materialisation is no longer consistent with the current knowledge base. Re-materialisation (reason()) is required, in order to obtain correct query answers.
        Parameters:
        query - a PositiveLiteral representing the query to be answered.
        includeNulls - if true, facts with TermType.NAMED_NULL terms will be counted. Otherwise, facts with TermType.NAMED_NULL terms will be ignored.
        Returns:
        a QueryAnswerCount object that contains the query answers Correctness and the number query answers, i.e. the number of facts in the extension of the query.

      • exportQueryAnswersToCsv

        Correctness exportQueryAnswersToCsv(PositiveLiteral query,
                                    String csvFilePath,
                                    boolean includeNulls)
                             throws IOException
        Evaluates an atomic query (query) on the implicit facts loaded into the reasoner and the explicit facts materialised by the reasoner, and writes its answers the .csv file at given path csvFilePath:
        An answer to the query is the terms a fact that matches the query: the fact predicate is the same as the query predicate, the Constant terms of the query appear in the answer fact at the same term position, and the Variable terms of the query are matched by terms in the fact, either named (Constant) or anonymous (NamedNull). The same variable name identifies the same term in the answer fact.
        A query can have multiple, distinct query answers. Each answers is written on a separate line in the given file.
        Parameters:
        query - a PositiveLiteral representing the query to be answered.
        csvFilePath - path to a .csv file where the query answers will be written. Each line of the .csv file represents a query answer, and it will contain the fact term names as columns.
        includeNulls - if true, answers containing terms of type NamedNull (representing anonymous individuals introduced to satisfy rule existentially quantified variables) will be included. Otherwise, the answers will only contain those with terms of type Constant (representing named individuals).
        Returns:
        the correctness of the query answers, depending on the state of the reasoning (materialisation) and its KnowledgeBase:
        • If Correctness.SOUND_AND_COMPLETE, materialisation over current knowledge base has completed, and the query answers are guaranteed to be correct.
        • If Correctness.SOUND_BUT_INCOMPLETE, the results are guaranteed to be sound, but may be incomplete. This can happen
          • when materialisation has not completed (reason() returns false),
          • or when the knowledge base was modified after reasoning, and the materialisation does not reflect the current knowledge base. Re-materialisation (reason()) is required in order to obtain complete query answers with respect to the current knowledge base.
        • If Correctness.INCORRECT, the results may be incomplete, and some results may be unsound. This can happen when the knowledge base was modified and the reasoner materialisation is no longer consistent with the current knowledge base. Re-materialisation (reason()) is required, in order to obtain correct query answers.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs regarding given file (csvFilePath).

      • resetReasoner

        void resetReasoner()
        Resets the reasoner. All implicit facts inferred by reasoning are discarded.
